metadata.title: The City of Too Much
metadata.subtitle: A city balancing between Protocol and Carnival
metadata.summary: Manage a living city that drifts between rigid order and absurd excess. Keep tension alive without collapsing into sterility or disintegration.
metadata.victoryCondition: Sustain interpretable tension for the required number of turns.
collapseConditions: Protocol collapse: the city becomes sterile, over-regulated, and unable to evolve.
Carnival collapse: coherence dissolves under excess, contradiction, and semantic overload.

persistentAnchors: same town hall with clock tower

motifs.name: Regulation Language
motifs.description: Formal rules and official restrictions become everyday speech.

motifs.name: Avian Governance
motifs.description: Birds gain civic agency and shape municipal life.

motifs.name: Symmetry Obsession
motifs.description: Geometry, uniformity, and controlled structure dominate the city.

motifs.name: Managed Spontaneity
motifs.description: Spontaneity is institutionalized, creating paradoxical tension.

motifs.name: Civic Absurdity
motifs.description: Official systems absorb absurd acts and normalize contradiction.

cards.text: A regulation of public behavior in the central square is introduced.
A Department of Common Sense Oversight is created.
An annual Day of Excess is officially established.
The municipality approves an official list of acceptable jokes.
City hall adopts a standard smile width for public servants.
A public hotline for complaints about excess is opened.
The city council approves an experimental Week of Illogic.
A code of rational speech is drafted and announced.
A Chief Coordinator of Surprises is appointed.
A facade symmetry law passes with full support.
Pigeons receive the right to attend council meetings.
Pigeons are issued official identification tokens.
A tax on excessive bird feeding is enacted.
Pigeons begin occupying public transport stops.
An Inspector of Pigeon Discipline is assigned.
Park signs with recommendations for sparrows appear overnight.
Rumors spread about an informal Winged Committee.
Birds begin ignoring traffic signs in broad daylight.
A Museum of Logic opens to the public.
A Festival of Spontaneous Ideas is launched citywide.
A mandatory pause before applause is introduced.
Residents start changing routes in perfect sync without explanation.
A contest for the most rational storefront sign is announced.
Facades receive new slogans about moderation in all things.
The square is temporarily renamed Center of Restraint.
A stage for weekly debates on order is installed.
Identical umbrellas suddenly appear throughout the city.
Street musicians perform only within a strict schedule of silence.
Road markings become perfectly symmetrical.
Streets are temporarily renumbered by degree of logicality.
Traffic lights begin changing without visible cause.
The city park is resectioned into strict geometric zones.
Loudspeakers broadcast daily instructions on moderation.
An Avenue of Paradoxes is officially opened.
Extra city hall steps are added for the sake of balance.
Signposts to non-existent districts begin appearing.
The central fountain starts operating on a rigid timetable.
Symbol-less flags appear on residential rooftops.
A fee for excessive seriousness is introduced.
Shops are required to use identical price tags.
Sale of overly bright scarves is prohibited.
Bakeries begin producing bread in strict square form.
A market for ridiculous inventions opens downtown.
Taxis begin traveling only in perfectly straight lines.
A license for improvisation becomes mandatory.
Citizens are advised to schedule spontaneity in advance.
Citizens begin reporting identical dreams across districts.
The city forgets why one old holiday ever existed.
A temporary inscription reading Too Much appears in the main square.
No one can recall who proposed the first regulation.
